title: Jeremy Corbyn grimaces after Boris Johnson tries to talk to him
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

Jeremy Corbyn didn’t seem very keen to talk to Boris Johnson this afternoon, judging from his expression.

The Labour leader was seen grimacing as the prime minister attempted to make small talk before the Queen’s Speech.

As they walked side by side, Boris Johnson seemed to be trying to chat to him, although we can’t hear what was said.

Jeremy Corbyn kept determinedly looking to the front instead of engaging, then made the grimace to a camera operator.

Labour peer Stewart Wood commented on a screen-grab of Mr Corbyn’s face, saying: ‘This should be Labour’s election poster.’

It immediately found a lot of attention online from people who noticed.

He didn’t seem keen to chat (Picture: Pixel8000)

I’m proud we have a leader who holds this silver spooned millionaire Tory boy in such contempt pic.twitter.com/fD7K3XOmxA — Liam Young (@liamyoung) October 14, 2019

We can’t be sure exactly what led to the politician grimacing, with some speculating he was worried for the safety of the cameraman filming them, who was walking backwards.

Jeremy Corbyn wasn’t the only Labour politician to appear bothered by their company.

Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell didn’t seem impressed by whatever Sajid Javid said to him, as he was also pictured with a stormy expression on his face.

It could have had something to do with Chancellor Sajid Javid announcing he is planning to hold a Budget just six days after the UK’s scheduled Brexit date.

They were walking to the House of Lords to hear the Queen’s Speech (Picture: Rex)

Mr Javid tweeted: ‘On 6th November I’ll deliver Britain’s first Budget after Brexit and set out our plan to shape the economy and deliver our infrastructure revolution.’

Responding to the announcement, shadow chancellor John McDonnell said: ‘We expect more of the same. An electioneering stunt rather than a budget to rebuild our stalling economy and reset the direction of our country.’

The Queen’s Speech today was the first of Mr Johnson’s premiership.

It is the only regular time when the three parts which make up Parliament – the sovereign, the House of Lords and the House of Commons – come together.

The Queen made the short trip to the Palace of Westminster from Buckingham Palace in the Diamond Jubilee State Coach accompanied by the Prince of Wales and the Duchess of Cornwall.
